I regret very much that he is going
to leave Turin this Spring. I fear
that we shall not be able to get
another minister who will
wholly fill his place. But 
we should not think too much

to the Master. - I have

letter so I hope you will excuse 
me if it is not very interesting

    Our thaw which commenced

the evening before you went home 
has not terminated yet; but
it has been raining more or 
less all day.

    Mr. Foot's little girl is very sick.

with brain feaver and her recovery
is considered very doubtful. Her 
father also is somewhat sick 
but has no feaver. The case
of this little girl creates a good 
deal of anxiety among the school
girls af. Mr. Northam's little
girl died so sudden, as she also 
was attending school here. We
miss Mr. Foot very much when he
is not at the Sabbath School
as he is so efficient as a Superintendant
and so universally liked.
Has Jennie sent for the Atlantic
Monthly yet? Wm has just
brought in a copy of the Jan.
No. which he borrowed to
read. So if she gets the Jan
No She need not send it 
to me and I can read this, 
I have purchased the 2nd
vol of "The American Conflict"
Is not the Cen. out yet? I
have not seen it. Hoping
none of our folks are sick
Write Soon,            Eddie

4 A.M.
         Turin Aug. 7th, 1867

Dear Friends,

               If I were not

too sleepy I would write you
a few lines, but - I will try. 
I expected to come down Mon.
morning, first train. A friend
of mine from here, Mrs. 
Rockwell, is going out to 
Middleton, Conn. and wishes
to go with us as far as
Springfield if we go that
way. I have not seen 
her but her daughter spoke 
to me about her going. I
expect to see her before 
I start so as to make

arrangements as to when

to start. She wishes to 

start on the P.M. 
train Mon. or Tues.
She is a very pleasant
old lady and will be
good company for us.

        We had installation

last - evening and
elected H.C. Northam W.C.T.
Mrs C. G. Riggs W.V.C.T. &c.
We are prospering finely
Our degree lodge numbers
71 and our sub. lodge 238
in good standing.

     If anything occurs

that the girls cannot 
go as agreed let me
know as soon as possible.
I send this note

with Wm. He will
probably return tomorrow 
P.M. I am looking
forward to next week
with high expectations.
I am afraid I shall not
see Mr. Parsons who I 
understand is coming 
about the 14th inst.
though he may stay
til I get back.  Cynthia,
Mr. Eben. Jones of Constableville
buried their little child 
yesterday about 4 mos
old.

     Love to all in haste
                 EW Everett

Turin, N.Y. Nov. 3rd, 67
             My Dear Sister and all
                           At Home
                                      I was

very glad to receive your
letter after two weeks of silence
on both sides and I guess 
more on my part. It had
really become a dread to me
to think of writing home
after neglecting you so long.
In a measure I can make 
your plea for not writing my 
own i.e. press of business for
during the last two weeks I have
had more to do than was convenient
for me to do. The new
goods have been coming
in and I had all the marking 
and puting away to do,
which left no time for
correspondence. I promised Jennie

a letter, the last time I wrote 
so before mailing this I must
gather up the fragments of 
that promise and write to her.

      Anna I am glad that you 

and Sarah got home so
comfortably and that the visit
East has done you so much
good. Hope you did not have
to walk from Worcester to the 
Junction or have your trunk
burst open at Springfield. I
will always remember that trip
with pleasure. Were it not for
those sharp corners and rough
edges which at the time 
were unpleasant we should remember 
so much about it. But who
can forget Worcester Junction
and Worcester after our experience!
Or who can forget such a 
White Mountain Excursion!!
Hark! Who! Not I.

      What a lovely fall we

have had indeed summer too.
It has been a model season

(if the expression is allowable) I
have been expecting for the last 
two weeks that each day was
the last pleasant one of the
series. But not until to day
has the weather taken a decided 
turn. To night it is cold 
and wet and dark and it 
is too near Election to expect
more pleasant weather just now.
We are to have a baloon ascension
here next Thursday if it is fair
weather or the first fair day thereafter
Mr. Squires the baloonist is from
Prospect, Oneida Co. and has
made over fifty ascensions.

       You say you wish I could come 

home soon. I wish so too as I 
have lots to talk about. But I
do not know how soon I can
come. I wish it was not so
far so I could come home once
in a while to spend the Sabbath
I have not been to meeting
to-day except S. School. It was
so rainy tonight that we had

no meeting. I have given 
up the charge of the library
and now have a class. Pray 
that I may be useful in this
new enterprise In my class 
are only three as yet - boys
of about fifteen.

    I was very sorry to hear that

brother Johns' health is so poor,
I wish I was out there with him.
Hope he is well now. I will try
to remember to enclose his letter 
in this to return. 

         I attended a wedding 

party last evening here in the
place all but the wedding
did not come off. But it
probably will a week from 
to-morrow. The gentleman
is from the west and the lady
has been living west some time
and has lately come home on
a visit and to be married. Her
fellow has come but they are not 
married yet as a good many suppose
they would be last evening. 
Love to you all from your brother E
Please write soon again.

Turin, Nov. 21, 1867,

My Dear Sister

               Please pardon me

for not answering your letter 
sooner. No Excuse but business.
I thank you for writing to me
as you did. Your letter deserved
a more prompt reply. Well, I do
not know what to say. I am
a little surprised but by no means
disappointed. Trust it is all right.
May God's blessing follow you.

      I have no time to write 

you a letter to=night but only
a note. Isaac Prichard has been 
in the store this evening. He is
helping his brother William 
move up near Martinsburg.
We have a good Templars Co.
Convention in Lowville next
Tuesday and Wednesday. Hope
I can go one day. We are 
very busy every day in the store

Mrs. Williams handed me the
enclosed last night and I 
promised to send it last night 
but forgot it Please have it
inserted in the Cen. in the
proper place if possible this
next number.

      All well. Much love

to all from your

           Brother Eddie

Turin, N.Y. Nov. 27th, 1867
 My Dear Sister
                  I have long intended to

write you a letter, which intention I am
now going to promulgate. It is seldom that
I hear from home now and they have not
mentioned about you but once. I am
anxious to hear how you are prospering in
your new project. Hope you are well and 
doing finely. When you receive this letter
I hope you will sit down and answer 
it. It must be very delightful in New York
now. Wish I could be there with you. It
would be so pleasant. To-morrow is 
Thanksgiving. The annual return of that
day always reminds me of home and absent
friends. May it remind me more of that
best of friends our bountiful Benefactor
who has been so kind to us during the
year - yes all our lifetime. I shall
think of you to-morrow while this letter 
is on its way hope you will think of 
me and pray for me.

For the last week it has been 

muddy but we have not had much 
rain. Our snow which for a week previous 
afforded quite good sleighing has all disapeared 
We are in need of rain and hope that
winter will not set in until we have our
usual fall rains. There was a Lord Templars
Convention at Lowville yesterday and today
I did not attend. Prof. E.W. Mason G.W.S
lectured here Monday eve. on his way to
Lowville. We had a good meeting and
initiated 15 after the lecture. Last 
evening the initiated at Lowville 69
after the evening meeting!

 Married;
      Last Sabbath, by Rev. J.W. Roberts,

Mr. John C. Jones to Miss Lucina Allen
This took place in the M.E. Church after
the services in the morning and your
brother was groomsman. That is about
as near as I expect to come to being
married for the present - near enough
was'nt it?

          There is a good deal of sickness 

about here - mostly feavers. I am 
blessed with good health. When do
you expect to come home?

I feel guilty that I have not written

to cosin Thomas. He was so kind to me when 
I was in N.Y. and I have neglected to
write so long - too bad! Well I will write 
to him in a few days. Where are you
boarding. I will direct this to his care
as that is the best I can do. What is
Coz. doing now? I am still with R.W. & F.
but do not know how long I shall remain
here. My time is up in about a week.
Will probably stay here this winter.

      We expect the cars will soon be

running to the Falls regular There has
been one train up to-day That is only
three miles distant. They will not
run any further this winter. William R.
Jones (son of Robt. R. Jones Bethel) is going to
be depot master there. I am going home
when the passenger trains run up to the
Falls. Hope I have got through staging 
over the planks to Boonville

      Have you heard Mr. Everett preach

and if so how do you like him? if 
not go and hear him next Sabbath
I liked him very much. O how I wish 
we had a pastor in our church.
Give my love to cousins Thomas & Elisabeth and
axcept the same yourself from Your Brother Eddie.

Turin, March 6th, 1868,

My Dear Sister

                 Your letter bearing

postmark of the 1st inst is 
just received this P.M. This
is the first mail we have had 
since last Saturday. Your letters
generally come through the same 
day but this is unusual. We
have about decided that
we could live without the
B.R.R.R. but it would be 
decidedly inconvenient.

      Your letter was doubly

welcome as it had really
a long time since I had
heard a word from home
and with four mails
coming to-gether I surely
expected one letter. I have
been feeling somewhat sad
and lonely to-day as it
is the anniversary of brother
Henry's death. I have been

thinking of him all day.
Last night I sat up with
the corpse of Mrs. Warren Jones,
(perhaps you did not know her)
and to-day attended the 
funeral as one of the 'bearers.'
I don't know when my mind
has wandered back over the
past as it has to-day. I
wish I could be at home
to-night. I wonder what
you are all doing. Perhaps
father has gone to prayer-meeting, 
but I hope he
is home if it storms as 
it does here. Yesterday was
the only pleasant day
we have this week. Snow
is about four and a half 
feet deep and some pitch-holes
are nearly as deep.
I send you three studs same 
as before and 2 sample pearl
S. buttons 15c per. Doz. I do not 
know anything about the fifteen

cents you say I lent you
but of course I will keep 
it if you say you owe it. 
I remit the bal., 25 cents.
Tell Sarah that if she ever get almost
sick because I am neglected
that I recomend a good dose 
or writing materials, rightly
put to-gether. I hope she
will try it. This remedy
is equally as god for well
as for sick persons. Try it.
I should like to see that
new dress of yours. I am
quite interested in your
affairs. And whatever you
see fit to communicate
to my is read with interest.

      I am sorry to know 

that John is no better. I
am afraid he is not enjoying
himself much since he
went back to Kansas. I must
write to sister Elisabeth. I wish
I could get you to write some

letters for me
They are having a 
Sociable at the G.T. Hall
to-night. They have been 
having them at the houses
and this is the first at the
hall. The object is to raise
money to carpet the floor
That will be done soon.
We have a Cabinet Organ.

    We have nothing now 

that would be pretty
for whit aprons? now.

    I think March can be

said to have come in like 
a lion this year. May it
go out as much like a 
lamb.

    I must bid you all

good night as I am very 
sleepy. More annon Eddie

Turin, 10 April 1868

Dear Friends at Home 

                     Perhaps you

will look for me to=morrow
as I mentioned something about
it in my last, but [moving]
to the fine sleighing we
are having we are quite
busy in the store and as
I am the only clerk it 
is difficult for me to leave
just now. Will try to come
next week. Pierce and
Clara were here to=day
They have your back, on
the hill. Expect to return
home to=morrow. Love to
all,              In haste

                    E.W. Everett

Turin, May 29, 1868

My Dear Sister

               Your letter should

have been answered sooner but
I put you off thinking you would 
care so much if I only wrote 
to the other girls. It deserves
a good letter in reply, but
I fear that my attempt tonight
will prove almost a failure.
I wish I could have another 
shorty visit with you soon.
But fear I cannot come home
yet - a while. O! you ought
to have been here yesterday!
we had one of the finest
balloon ascensions I ever
witnessed. There were a great
many people in town which
of course kept us very busy.
I did not go up to the fair

grounds when the balloon was
inflated but saw it from the 
store. There was apparently 
but very little wind, so it
went up very nearly straight
for one or two hundred feet
and sailed off majestically directly north.
Mr. Squires who made the
ascension is the one who
made an ascension at Lowville
last fall. The balloon went
directly over the village of
Lowville and he landed just
outside of the corporation.
making the trip of eleven 
miles in forty five minutes
not very fast for
an air ship but so nice
and landing just where
he wanted to.

    We had a beautiful and

refreshing rain this afternoon.

You write about the death

of Jennie Griffths. I do not 
remember her. I am ashamed 
to say that I have forgotten 
some of those with whom I
used to be quite well acquainted
but I think it is partially 
owing to the fact that there
are so many of the same
name. Am sorry to hear that 
Morris Griffiths and Griffith James
are sick. But I hope they
are both well ere this.   

    The [     ] came last

eve. Guess our folks are
smarter than they used to 
be. Is cousin Ottie there yet?
give my love to her and tell
her I am coming out to
Chicago to see her sometime.
I saw the account in the Cen.
of the marriage of High
and Mary Ann. Tell them

that when they get to keeping
house I am coming down to
see them. Hen are you and 
Cynthia coming up to see your
brother? Write me before
hand if you can so that
I may know when to expect
you. Hope you will come
soon while it is pleasant.
We have finally engaged a
minister for four months.
He is a student and has one
year yet to attend school.
I hope he is the right 
man to do us good.
I am expecting to hear after
from home to know how you
all are. Tell Anna I will
try to write to her soon
Hope she still continues 
to gain

         Yours with much Love,
                       E.W. Everett

Turin, 16th July 1868,

My Dear Sister

                    I suppose you

are "home again" and hope 
you are well and feeling 
refreshed after your visit
I hope enjoyed your
visit as well as I did, but
I think we both would have
enjoyed it better if I had
been at liberty more to take
you around You know 
there are a good many 
places that we intended
to call but did not have
time. I really wish I could
return your visit with you all.
Is Anna improving any?

I ought to write her a 
letter. Will try to bear it in
mind. Did you know that 
Mrs. Bush died during the 
night before you left?
She was buried yesterday
afternoon
at four o'clock.
Last night we organized
a Grant Club and are
going to work for the
campaign. Maj. J.M. Mascott
os Pres. and L.J. Lewis Secy
another item of news - the
toll gate just this side of
Houseville was burned last
night. There was no one
living in it the family
that lived in it had just
moved out. And the 
family that were going 
to move in have decided 
not to. It was probably

set on fire by some one
and no one seems to feel
very bad as the plank road
is mizerable and the gate
will probably never be rebuilt.
The democrats lay it to the
Grant Club, but we lay it
to a committee from the
"Cu Clux Clan." The telegraph
was attached to one corner of 
the building and of course
the wire was welded, and
communication cut off so
that The Turin Fire + Hose Co.
could not be sent for.

    We have got one front in

all except the doors so I
will have to bunk on the 
counter again to=night and
will be up in the morning 
in time to mail this
letter. Your mitts are here

I can not find them
to night to send them. 

    We had a temperance

lecture at our church this
evening but I did not go.
They say it was good, and
pretty well attended.

    I am anxious to know 

what you hear from Mr. B.
I trust it will be all right
but I hope you wont worry 
about it. Write soon and
tell me how you got home
and how you all do. 

    Love to all at home
           from your brother
                          Eddie

1860's
                           Tues. morn

Dear Sister

    I received your letter

last night. There was plenty
of room for it in the carraige.
But do not worry so about
coming home. We would like 
to have you go with us to the
Society but we dont want you
to hurry awfully for anything
else. Hope Mary and Brannie
(and we wish Ella) will come
with you. Father says you
had a letter get some money of
Uncle. We hardly dare venture to

send any this morn for fear you
will not get this before you come.
We are getting about pretty well.
We washed with lye water
yesterday. I take care of Auntie
nights and she is quite good
Get us 1 pound of pulverized
white sugar. Something brewing
for the 4th. up to the big farm
yesterday morning I wrote a 
note to Rev. E.l. burtis making 
some inquiries relative to the
most pressing needs of the wounded
and also as to where it would be 
best to send the box. Last night

I received as reply giving full directions 
as to where he thought was the 
best place to send, also containing 
other most interesting and valuable
information. He advises at
present to send to Fortres Monroe
as that now is the best point 
from which to forward supplies
and will be, he says, until
Grant takes Richmond I am 
glad you heard that sermon 
I hope you will not forget it all
before you came home. 
Eddie is [sharing] and must soon
have this. Mary is milking alone

and I must hurry to help her. I help
milk every day

           Cynthia

John W. Roberts has received
his photograph which I mentioned
about in the other
letter, so you need not
trouble yourself about it if
you have not been there.
How are they selling calice
in Utica now. We are selling 
for [2/ and 2/9], a nice time
to buy a new calice dress. 

                    Eddie.

Remsen Aug 27th

Dear Sisters Three & All,

         I have but a 

few minutes to spare, but
will improve them in
writing yo a few lines
to apprize you of me
safe arrival her to=day.
I reached New York
Sat. morn. Found boy
Thomas in the afternoon 
and he spent all his 
time with me until
I started home last
night. I had a very
pleasant time in N.Y.
Visited the Park, (Central)
[Barnenn's], Greenwood,
Coney Island and had a

bath in the sea. I did
not enjoy my visit in 
Boston much as it
rained all the time.
I am going to Turin
to=night. Am feeling
first rate, and hope
you all do the same.
Axcpet much love
Write to me soon I
will leave this letter
for somebody else to 
finish.

         In great haste.
     From your brother
             Eddie

Wed, Morn - We had Sarah's
letter last eveg. - Were very glad to
hear that Anna is getting along so
well - we are very busy with Cen.

        all well this morn.-

love to you all - Your Father

Turin, May 16, 1871.
  Dear Sister,
         I have finally 

got the table started. Sent
it to the depot today and it
will be in Remsen at the
same time as this letter.

    I called at William P. Williams;

this afternoon and to my 
surprise found Clara and 
little Lyman there. He is a 
fine boy but not as heavy
as Carroll. Have you seen him?
Where is Uncle Nathaniel now?
We were very glad to have even 
a short visit with him. Hope
we shall see him again before 
he returns. Hugh Lewis is no
better. I fear it will be some
time before he will be well

enough to be in the store
again. We are having a 
nice warm rain tonight.
It is very much needed.
We are all well. Hope Anna
will make us a visit soon. 
They have got all through painting 
the house, and we are better
prepared to entertain visitors
than when you and Uncle
were here.     Love to all

                    Your aff. bro.
                         Eddie.

Turin, July 15, 1871.
   Dear Friends, 
    We reached home

all safe at six o'clock P.M.
It may seem to you a good while
to be on the road but I will
explain. Our buggy was
pretty well filled, you know, 
and we had the small satchell
in front of us and there was 
nothing to prevent it sliding out
so when we were looking at
it the mischievous thing 
slid out, and we did not 
miss it until we were near 
Alder Creek, We went back about
two miles and found it near 
Penygraig. No one having passed
the spot since we did, it was
on the middle of the road.

We reached Boonville about
one. Staid three hours and
took dinner and rested nicely .
When I got to the store I was
a little alarmed to learn
that our store had been
entered by a burglar on Thursday
night but hapily he was
frightened away without taking
or disturbing anything. I was
through a mere accident that
Mr. [E] came to the store
about twelve o'clock and as
he entered the door he heard
the noise of someone stepping 
on the floor rear of the 
store and at that moment his 
hair assumed a virtigal position
and he immediately retreated and
closed the door but before he 
could obtain any help the chap
got out the same way he entered.

which was through the 
cellarway of the adjoining
store in front which was 
very carelessly left exposed
and the cellars being [c]
the thief gained egress to the
store through our trap door.
The next morning he was tracked
across the road both coming and
going until the same rubber
tracks as were seen the morning
after Mr. Whites' bonds were taken.
I think there must be an 
organized band of burglars
about here or at least some
persons in our place who
are connected with such a 
gang. We are taking precaution
that the above may not
be repeated.

    We are all well

but rather tired. Will write

again soon,

    Love to all

at home

     Eddie

P.S. Did Lewis get all 
his hay in today? Hope he
had help enough to improve
the good weather. I enclose
a few samples and if any
suit return the sample &c. 

                     E.W.E

Turin. May 8, 1876.
  Dear Sister
    Your Kind letter, with

flour seeds for Mate from Anna, also
the copy of those verses from Cynthia
for which Mate is much obligated - I was
going to say your letter was received Sat.
eve. and I am going to answer it
promptly this time. There is 9 yards more
of that Blk. Cashmere. You can have just
what you want of it as the rest will sell
for sacks. Let me know at once so
that I can bring it with me when
I am on my way to New York. The
potatoes are $2. per Bushel, so $1. s. worth
would be 1/2 Bushel - that amount, 
if they are cut up and planted
with 3 eyes in a hill will goo
a good ways. I will save the 40th

Maple Sugar for you, and if you
want the potatoes, they could be packed
together. If this pleasant weather continues
a few days potatoes ought to be put in
the ground this week. The prospects are
that there will be feed for cattle in
a week. I am glad you have
got a new horse. What are you 
going to do with Lye?

    I was very sorry to hear of

Elias Jones + Hugh Jones' sickness. Hope
Hugh's life may be spared.

    I think of going to New York 

the last of this week or next Monday.
William P. Williams is going today. Trade seems
to be backward this spring but he have
sold $1200. worth more during March
and April this year than during the
same months last year. That looks
encouraging for the centennial this year

    In regard to that money, We want 

to have the land surveyed before

any more papers are made out
so as to be sure that the bounderies
are all right and the ground is
not dry enough for that yet, but
I would like to get the money before
I go to New York. If I should come
home Thursday could you let me 
have it? A draft on N.Y. would be
the best. If you could do this
and had as leave to do it as
not I will stop off over night
Thursday and go to N.Y. Friday morning
If you had rather wait until you
get the papers do not be afraid to
say so but I will see that you
get them all right within a 
month. Please write me as 
soon as convenient and let
me know. 

    It is mail time.
                   In haste,
                             E.W.E.

Turin, Jan. 16, 1877,
  Dear Brother + Sister,
    You will

probably be somewhat surprised to
receive a letter from me as
you know I am not much of
a hand to write but as I have
a good excuse I will write a few
lines although it is after 10 P.M. 
and I ought to be at home. I 
suppose our folks at home have
written you that I made them a 
short visit. I was glad to find
mother so comfortable after another
of her sad accidents. It is remarkable
that her general health is so good. She
has the best of care and that accounts
for her good health. It is fortunate
that Mary was at home at the
time of the accident and that she
remains with mother.

I brought the enclosed letter
from cousin Mary Ann Roberts
home with me to read and 
they have written me to send 
it to you. We are sorry to
hear that William is no better
there than at Remsen. This
is a severe winter and perhaps
that has something to do with 
it. Have you decided what you 
will do next summer? I suppose
you hardly know what will be
best. Tell Hattie that we
saw Mr. Nibecker for just a 
few minutes at the close of 
a temperance lecture at Turin
a few weeks ago. He was
here all day but I was out
of town when he called at
the store and so failed to
see him until just before
he started home. We were 
very sorry that we did not

Know of his being in town
also that he did not call at
the house as Mate was at home,

    We have been having a

series of revival meetings at the
M.E. church for a number of 
weeks past and upwards of
125 have turned their faces 
heavenward and the churches
have been revived. The meetings
still continue. We hope that
Abbie has met with a change of
heart also many others of our
friends. 

    We are all quite well. 

We are not having as much snow

good but I could not get it cashed because I did not have power of atty to sign your name in writing.  I was very glad to get your letter at Wilkes Barre written the 22.  I do not intend to go to Pittsburgh on this trip.
I am anxious to hear how Sarah is getting along.  Hope to hear that sshe is riding out regularly again and that she expects to be ready when I return to go to Brantingham.  We are having beautiful weather.  Have not bought or needed an umbrella yet.  I got me a thin coat & another linen vest.  I wrote the above at the depot at Plymouth while wating for the train.  Have just arrived at Wilkes Barre.  I enclose a P.O. Order for $40.
I am quite well.  I took dinner with Rev. Mr. Jarrett at Plymouth Tuesday and had a very pleasant all there again.

this A.M.  He left Collinsville with his family the same week that I left Turin.  Of course he and his family were glad to see any one from Lewis Co.  One of the little girls remarked "I wish some one from Collinsville would come here every day to dinner".
With much love to each of you from your wandering brother.
Edward.

Centralia,  Aug 4, 1881
Dear Sister,
I wrote you a card about a week ago to enquire about R.R. Lickets to the west during this time of Railroad war, requesting an answer to Danville.  I did not receive any mail at Danville, and knowing that the low prices for fare cannot continue long.  I enclose herewith a P.O.Order for twenty dollars and I will state my plan and want you to use your own good judgment in the matter.  I see by the papers that some of the roads are selling tickets at regular price but with a rebate so as to make the real fare from N.Y. to Cincinnatti only $7. and from N.Y. to Chicago $7. and from N.Y. to St. Louis $10.75 &c but I have not

seen account of reduction to any points west of St. Louis.  I intend to go home in about two weeks and thought by getting a ticket from N.Y. to Cin. I could go to the Vermont slate quarries with the cofiant and thence to N.Y. and thence to Cin. Ohio.  And then I might use the other tickets (if I got two) to go to St. Louise, Mo & visit the Welsh settlements in Mo. and in Kansas and visit John and my other relatives in Kansas.  I suppose these tickets would be as good as any and good for one year.  I want you to buy me a ticket to Cincinnatti O. $7.  and one to St. Louis, Mo.  $10.75.  The price may have changed a little, up or down, but I want you to use your own judgment and keep the tickets at present.  Get the St. Louis ticket over the central if you can or over the Erie if you cannot over the

Central.  Possibly you can let some one use it as far as Utica as I would not want to use it from N.Y.  The P.O. Order is on Station E. which I believe is your station.  Please write me at Slatington or to Providence.  Will be at the former about the 9th and latter about the 12 or 13th inst.  I am doing quite well.  Am on the second Hundred of the Cofiant.  Am quite well and enjoying my trip.  I go to Shenandoah this P.M. thence to Mahavoy City.  Have heard nothing from home for a week  Expect to hear when I get to Hazleton tomorrow.
With much love from your brother
E.W. Everett
P.S. -- If the tickets only cost $7 and $10.75 = $17.75 you will have money left but the price may vary.
E.

Turin,  Dec 4, 1881
Dear Sisters,
As Carroll and Charlie have written each a letter I will write a little to send with theirs.  It is just 17 years today since I came to Turin to work.  There have been a great many changes since then.  Although I have not been as successful as I expected yet I have more things to be thankful for than to find fault or complain about.
The boys are very much pleased with their Youth's Companion..  I hope they will make good use of them.  They are now anticipating

a great deal of pleasure at Christmas tree.  There are to be two here as usual, one at each church.
I am so glad you have got those blinds up.  Hope you can keep the parlor warm and comfortable now in the coldest weather.  What is the down comfortable you spoke of Jennie on your card?  How is it made.  I have just bought a new matress for $4 for the bed in the sitting room.
We are all well as usual and send love.
Edward.

Turin,  Jan 15, 1882
Dear Sister,
I have sent the deed to Mr. Winston as requested.  I had ascertained the amount of tax against the premiums but had done nothing more.  I have had too much to attend to at home to do that business.
I went to see Sarah last Wed. returning the same day.  I found Sarah very low indeed.  She seemed quite anxious to see you -- not so much that she thought you could do anything for her but that she wanted to see you.  I received a card from Jennie last eve saying the were looking for you, but I send this to N.Y. lest you may be detained from coming.  I wish we could see you

when you come, but suppose you would not feel like sparing the time.  Do not know as it would be as well for Sarah to have us both there the same day.  I fear Sarah will not last long she is so very weak and takes so little nourishment.
Mate is getting along quite well although she does not gain strength as fast as she wishes she could.  She takes the entire care of the baby.  We weighed little Robert Allen this eve and found that he weighs 12 1/4 lbs.  He is a healthy boy and is growing fat.  The other boys are quite well and improving their time in school.  We all send love
Your brother
Edward

Turin, N.Y.  Jan 24, 1882
My Dear Sister,
We were quite disappointed in not receiving a word from some of you tonight to know how our dear sister has been today but I know your time is limited as well as mine.  It is after 12 P.M. and the rest of the family are in sweet repose but I must write you tonight as I do not have time in the mornings except for a hasty card.  Our girl is not coming back and we must look up another one.  Carroll and I do what work is done about the house (except the care of little Robert) as Mate is not strong enough to do much out of her room.  She was feeling quite poorly this morning as the room got a little to cool during last night

but she is feeling better tonight.  Her tooth has not troubled her much for a day or two.  Do not know as it will answer to have it extracted while she is so weak.  I enclose the check received for the John Evans note.  I have made statements of the account as seems best to me but you need not use them unless you think they are better than the others.  You will notice that I have omitted the words.  "Received Payment" as you will need to go before a notary public or a Justice of the Peace and make affidavit to the papers that the account (& note) is correct and not paid &c.  I do not know but it will be necessary to make a copy of the endorsements also which are on the note but do not think it necessary.  I endorse the note Jane received about Morgan Edwards and Maggie says Nelson is his address

He did not send pay.  I think you better send him a book and a bill for the same.  I ought to go there in the spring.  Is Mary still with you?  I hope she is as it will be very hard for you to spare her, but I know it is very hard also for her to be away from her business so long.  I fear this intense cold weather has had a bad effect on Sarah.  It is very trying for those in health but what must it be for her!  Hope you will succeed in keeping the room of an even temperature.  Where does the bed stand now?  What nourishment does she take now?  How is her month?  Does she talk less or more than when I saw her last?  I wish very much I could be with you more but how can I?  When we get a girl I will try to come down again.  There is a great deal said about us here about the necessity of vaccination and I presume it will be made

compulsory in our village upon those who have not been vaccinated within a certain length of time.  Our boys have never been vaccinated.  Has Mary any vacceen with her that is all right?
I must close now and retire and hope for a word from you tomorrow (Wednesday) and every night as we feel very anxious.  With much love to you all and especially to Sarah from us all.
Your brother,
Edward

Turin  Jan 26th 1882
Dear sisters
Have just rec'd Jennies and Anna's letters.  Carroll & Charlie went for the mail as Edward did not go back to the store after tea.  I have just got Edward in bed after soaking his feet and giving him a hot cup of tea he is sweating nicely now, he took some cold yesterday and day before he came home last night feeling chilly said he thought he would feel all right in the morning.  he was uneasy all night and and restless

this morn. felt better and went to the store he came home to tea tonight feeling chilly now he is sweating nicely in bed.  Jennie went in search of a girl today for us.  we have got along nicely so far I have not ventured in the kitchen much till today.  we live mostly on oatmeal & milk & rice baked apples &c.
I would like very much to go to Remsen & see Sarah and you all.  it seems a long time since I have seen any of you  hope E can go soon.  am so glad Caroline is there with you and also  [illegible]

John E.  I think of you often.  The baby is very good.  I think we will all him Robbie as S spoke of.  The boys are a great help.  I sometimes think Carroll does as well as Sabbie only he can't wash.  he did iron a little for me the other day.  we have not taken the baby up in the night once since Caroline went away.  We are very glad to hear from you nearly every day.  was glad that Mary could come home for a short time.  it must be a great

comfort to you all.  wish a great deal of love to you all and especily to Sarah the dear child I will bid you all good night.
From sister    Mate

Upper Sandusky, Ohio  Aug 25 / 84
Dear Sisters & All
I am now on my way from Venadocia to Radnor, 7 mi north of Deleware.  I have to wait here two hours to make connections.  Venadocia is a right smart place to raise corn, wheat pork &c and there a great many good people there, but from my observation I should say it is a better field for selling "Cofiant Dr. Rowlands" "Rhodd Main" &c than those for my business.  I was aware of this before going out but found it more so than I expected.  I would not have been so anxious to go there but I wanted to see Wm Williams Delphon formerly who owed $16.  But when I found him he claimed

that he had not received the Cen but for one year after comin from Cincinnatti & that he had paid in advance for that year.  Probably some other Wm. Williams got it from the P.O.  So I did not make any collections at V.  I sold 15 of the memoir and 6 of Uncle Lou at 30 cts.  I collected $20 at Somer that would not be paid without going there for it.  Have collected enough so far to pay my fare.  I sent you a P.O.O. from Lima for $50.  The 21st in a letter to Mate.   I also enclose a P.O.O in this for #30.  I received a P.O. from Mate dated the 18th, at V.  That is all the mail I got there.  Write me next at Columbus or Granville.  Will be at Deleware over Sabbath.
Please pay Rev. E. Davies $.160 which I received from Evan Evans Somer

for the Cen for 1882 so that it may be acknowledged by him.
If you think best you might have the enclosed notice inserted on the second page of next Cen cover.  It may open the way for me in some places.
In haste & with lots of love to Mate, the children & all.
Your brother,
Edward

Turin,  Jan 24, 1883 at Home
Dear Sisters,
I have been sick with a cold and bilious trouble as usual since Saturday P.M. was not out of the house Sunday and ought not to have been out Monday but was in the store until tea time.  Since then I have not been out, but am much better this P.M. and hope to get out to the store tomorrow.  This accounts for your not hearing from us sooner.  We recd your letter Sat eve saying you expected to come this week & hope to see you before the Sabbath.  Hope Anna will be very careful to not take more cold.  John Roberts is off on his wedding trip and Geo Allen drives stage nearly altogether this week.  We think you will find it warm & comfortable here when

you come.  Carroll and Charlie are the only well ones we have now.  Mate has had a cough for about three weeks.  Her [?] is about well.  Baby is not having the whooping cough very hard,if indeed he is having it at all.  He coughs more nights than day times but is rather worrisome through the day.  George is not staying here now.  It has been quite storming so far this week but we hope the last of the week will not be so.  Please enquire of Joe Roberts if there is a box of books thre for me from Newburgh, Ohio and pay the freight.
We received a letter from John Eddie this morning containing the tin type of John and myself.  also a photo of John E. Y his father.  I am thankful the former did not reach home before I did as it might have created some anxiety about my health.  It seems to me that Tom ought to be north $75 or $80.  He would make a good team house and the spring halt would not hurt him for teaming.  With love to each.  hoping to hear from you tonight starting when you are coming.  Wish you were here so I could visit with you while I am sick.  Hope to see you very soon however.  Your brother     Edward.

Turin,  April 6, 1883
Dear Sisters
Yours of the 228th M is still unanswered and it is time for us to have another letter from you but we cannot expect one until that one is answered.  I have written to John Eddie answering his questions &c.  I received a P.O. order for $19.85 from Rev. R. Pierce, Long Creek in payment for books and I have paid your bill at W.P. Wms $12.75 and the balance I hold in my hands expecting to get more to send with it to you.  Thos. R. Evans promises to pay the $80 in about a week and when it is paid I will send it to you.

When Mate got up yesterday morning she was all broken out with mock measals or Roseola.  The Missionary Meeting was appointed to be at our house yesterday but as the roads are impassable for horses there was no one there from out of the village and most of those who came did not stay as they were afraid they might catch it.  Rev. Mr. Webber came out Wed eve to attend the prayer meeting on foot and staid to attend the funeral of the father of Wm. B. Jones who works for Mrs. Cadwell Dewey today.  He came to the Miss. Meeting but did not stay.  No one staid to tea but Mr. Bowe and Mary Roberts.  Mate is some better today.  Last Monday when Mate was washing she missed Robbie and found him on his way up stairs on the fourth step.  The next day after she had baked two tins of ginger bread and put them away on the shelf in the pantry she missed him again and this time found him with one little fist full of the cake out of each tin enjoying himself first rate.  He is pretty well but worries a good deal cutting teeth.
They have to take the nail to the

Falls on a hand sled as the roads are so high and soft that a horse cannot travel them.
Last Tuesday was my birthday.  It has been but a few short years since I was twenty.  Ten years ahead from that standpoint seemed very long.  But time sped on and I was thirty.  The next ten years of my life is the sad part of my song.  The greater part of our group have left us and now I'm forty.  Yes the youngest of us all iss growing old.  This busy life will soon be passed but this thought should not cause us pain rightly use our time as it passes.
I am glad you are enjoying yourselves sso well and that you have plenty of oranges so cheap.  I do not think it best for you to send us a box.  I am afraid me could not use them before they would spoil.  I did not see Rev. Mr. Morris of Bradford.  I did not go there.  He attended the Cymanfa at

Charleston Lirgaler and went home before the meeting at Blossburg.  I was at the latter and then went to Charleston so I did not see him.  I would like very much to become aquainted with Cousin Robert.  Perhaps I may at some future time.  The sidewalks from the house to the store are nearly all bare.  It seems good to see the snow disappear so quietly.  We have had no rain but it is wasting at top & bottom this mild sunny weather.  Mrs. Lyman is some better.  Mrs. Carter is alsso some better but has been very low for a long time.
When I was at Long Creek, Iowa I saw a young lady about 18 years of age who had been sick and confind to her bed for about two years with spinal disease, much the same as sister Sarah.  She had heard of Sarah's sickness and recovery and wanted to know if Dr. Strong is still living and if there is any help for her.  I promised to write to you, Mary, about her case and that you would know more about the treatment she had as you were with her.  When I saw her, her face was bloated and she was very white or pale

Turin,  June 13, 1883
Dear Sisters
I can hardly realize you are so near as we have heard so little from you.  We are having so much rain that I suppose the work does not progress rapidly in the garden.  It gives the weeds a good chance to start.  I would like very much to spend a few dayss there with you, but suppose I cannot at present.  Wish you would come and make us a visit after you get the garden started.  Now the fare on the R.R. is reduced it will not cost as much as it did.  When do you look for John Eddie.  We are in telephone communication with

Constableville, Boonville, Rome, Houseville, Lowville, Port Leyden, Greig &c and expect soon to be on speaking terms with Remsen.  The office here is in the Post office.  Did Mary move and get settled before you left N.Y?
I suppose you miss Tom.  I see him pass nearly every day with the meat cart.  Do you get good meat this summer?  Jane drove out here a week ago last Friday and took Callie back with her on Monday.  I suppose you have seen them.  I did not know until then that she had been having a new wing put up in place of the old back wing.  Have you been there yet?
Shall we send the trunk to you by freight and what shall we put in it.

Does Mr. Richard make butter or send the milk to the factory?
It is nearly mail time so I must close this now.  We are all well.  Robbie is quite well and growing.  I think he has changed a good deal since you saw him.  He wants to be out all the while when it is pleasant.  He walks out on the piazza back and forth alone.  He likes to have some one lead him out on the sidewalk in front of the house to meet me when I come home to meals.  The mosquittos have been making free plunder of his cheeks and forehead.  Hope we shall have a letter from you soon.
With much love.
Edward

Turin,  June 30, 1883
Dear Sisters
I have now received two full letters from Jennie and have only replied by postal cards but have intended to write you a letter sooner but something has hindered me so that I only had time to write a postal.  We are always glad to get your letters and wish we might yet have a visit with you soon.  Hope we may in the course of the summer.  We should all enjoy it very much.  Mate and the boys made you such a long visit last summer that we we would not expect to make

you a long visit this summer.  They will be glad to spend a part of their vacation there.  Their school closed yesterday.  Carroll and Charlie passed in all their studies in the examination.  Carroll passed 100 in Geography and Physical Geography and stood high in his other studies.  They have gone down to their Uncle jimmie's today strawberrying.  Berries are quite plenty.  Abbie and her children are down there and also her mother.  Griff went to New York and Philadelphia Monady and expects to return tonight.  Little Arthur has been sick for three or four days -- he has a very sore mouth & is bilious.  Charlie is well and the other boys escaped without taking the mumps.  Robbie is

quite worrisome.  I think his eye teeth are troubling him.  He is quite fleshy.  He goes up stairs and out doors alone when allowed to do so.
Am glad you are to have a visit from Cousin Mary.  Wish we might have a visit from her soon.  Hope she & Fanny will visit us this summer.  I must close now to get this in the mail and finish what I have to say in another letter.
With lots of love
E.W.E.

P.S. -- What is sister Mary's address now?

Turin,  June 22 / 83
Dear Sisters
Your good letter was welcomed last eve.  I will write you a few lines this eve lest I fail to write tomorrow morning as I did this morn.  Thank you for writing so much news, Charlie has had the mumps quite light.  He is nearly well.  The others have not come down yet.  Abbie & her family are with us, also mother Allen.  Griff & Abbie, and Mate have been to hear Mrs. Margaret Jones lecture at Music Hall, and have just gone home.  Am sorry you cannot go with us to B. Lake but perhaps it would be too tiresome for Anna to go with so many children.  Perhaps there will be a chance to go again.  Robbie is a great heavy boy.  Love from     E.W.E.

Turin,  July 27, 1883
Dear Sister Jennie & all
Your postal came to hand about 8 o'clock last eve.  We are very glad Mary and Anna are coming to make us a visit but do not want them to leave you behind and we will all enjoy the visit so much more if you come with them.  Mate says "write to have Jennie come too, we have plenty of room for them all to sleep and a plenty to eat and a plenty of berries."  Mate and the children are still at her brother's.  I have taken advantage of her absence and painted the kitchen floor.  It looks much better and is most

dry.  After closing the store last night I went down to tell them of your coming so they would be sure to come home today.  They were intending to come this eve.  They will stay and pick some more berries today so as to have some nice, fresh ones when you come.  Jim is nearly through haying -- hasx been very busy this week and was glad to have Mary's help to milk.  Hope Joh Eddie can visit us when he gets through haying.
The stage usually gets here at 8 or 8:30 P.M. so you will probably get here before dark.  Now Jennie I hope you an arrange to come with them.  And then we an all be together to make

our plans to go to Brantingham if it is thought advisable.  We received a postal from Emporia yesterday.  They arrived safely at home on Saturday P.M. all well and not much fatigued.  They found ripe peaches at Emporia.
With love to all
from your brother
Edward.

Turin,  Aug 11 1883
Dear Sister Anna & All
We received your letter last eve with the fancy cards..  They are very fine.  Hope Charlie will have such a good time that he wont be homesick any more.  Mr Williams and Pierce are talking of driving out to Steuben next week and if they go Dwight and Irving will go with them.  The M.E. Sabbath School of Martinsburg have an Excursion to the Thousand Islands today.  Fare from Glendale & return $1.30.  Several have gone from here.  Sill Holden & Carrie, Byron Litchfield

and Lillie.  Ev Prichard and Jennie and others.  They drove to Glendale Started about 5-30 A.M. from here and take the regular train Mr. Cornish and family have gone with their team to visit friends near Rome.
The farmers about here are making good use of their time this fine weather to finish their haying  Many stacks are being made.  The crop is very heavy.
Mr Cruikshank and family and some of their friends, making a large load report having a fine time at the Lake the day you went home.
We are all well.  Robbie was up at about half past five this morning.  He has got a new pair of shoes.
hope we shall have a postal from the boys tonight.

Did they get their tooth brushes, and do they use them?
Have the boys finished weeding the garden?  We get four eggs every day now.
Love to all from your brother.
Edward

Turin,  Aug 27, 1883
Dear Sisters,
I engaged a basket of berries of P. Bidinger's brother to be sent to Remsen on this evenings train by Express at 7 cts per qt.  He lives at the Falls and brings nice berries to Turin every day.  He took the basket.  Do not know how many berries he will put in the basket.  Let me know if they are nice.  The boys left their tooth brushes there.  Please send them by mail.  Did Carroll leave an old coat?  Mate & the three boys go to jimmie's this A. .  The boys to pick hops.  Robbie is not very well.  Has the diarrhea but is some better.
With love to all.
E.W.E.

Dear Sisters,
Anna's postal came Sat eve.  it seems you have not heard from Jennie after she left us.  Mrs. S.R.
